content:
U.S. Air Quality tag:alg.umbc.edu,2008-07-13:/usaq//1 2015-03-11T14:46:06Z The Smog Blog Movable Type 4.3-en Increased AOD in the Rocky Mountain Region. Fires in Great Plains, Southeast, and Pacific Northwest Regions tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5403 2015-03-11T14:28:11Z 2015-03-11T14:46:06Z The MODIS Aqua AOD image, below left, shows elevated values of AOD in the Rocky Mountain Region and light bands of increased AOD are apparent in the Plains Region, Texas and the Gulf of Mexico. The KNMI OMI NRT NO2... John Sullivan The MODIS Aqua AOD image, below left, shows elevated values of AOD in the Rocky Mountain Region and light bands of increased AOD are apparent in the Plains Region, Texas and the Gulf of Mexico. The KNMI OMI NRT NO2 product below right, shows increases in NO2 throughout the troposphere. Cloud coverage has made the measurement difficult in the center of the country. There appears to be an increase in the Great Lakes, Northeast, and Southwest regions. For this reason, there may be some increased nitrate aerosol and particulate formation that will affect air quality at the surface.



Below left, courtesy NOAA HMS, shows the fire locations throughout the country today. There is an increased in fires in the Plains, Pacific Northwest, and Southwest regions. Below right, courtesy EPA Airnow, shows the animation of the AQI values for the day. Code oranges were observed in the Great Lakes region, which is mostly due to regional sulfate aerosols. Code oranges were also observed in the Rocky Mountain region due to wildfire smoke and aerosols.
]]> Dry Air and Strong Winds Fuel Fires in NW; Elevated AOD in NE tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5402 2015-03-10T03:59:00Z 2015-03-10T06:18:43Z Mild winter conditions have sparked an early fire season in the Pacific Northwest, with smoke from burns concentrated over Northern Idaho and Southern Oregon (HMS Fire and Smoke Product, top left). Fires such as those in and around Springdale, Washington... Farrah Daham Mild winter conditions have sparked an early fire season in the Pacific Northwest, with smoke from burns concentrated over Northern Idaho and Southern Oregon (HMS Fire and Smoke Product, top left). Fires such as those in and around Springdale, Washington are amplified by relatively strong wind gusts and dry atmospheric conditions (NOAA WPC Surface Analysis, top right), fueling the brush fires in Washington County. The smoke being produced from these fires has affected air quality in the region, reaching levels of Moderate to USG in Northern Idaho (EPA AirNow PM2.5 AQI Loop, bottom left). Fires can also be seen in the central Plains States, producing light to moderate smoke over Kansas and Nebraska. Elevated AODs in the Great Lakes Region (MODIS AOD, bottom right) could possibly be due to smoke carried over from these fires by southwesterly winds. Smoke from burnings in the Southeast are also affecting air quality today, especially in central Georgia, where the AQI reached Unhealthy (Code Red).

]]> Weekend Edition: Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups in Pennsylvania tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5400 2015-03-08T01:55:38Z 2015-03-08T02:05:23Z Two areas of the US had poorish air quality on Saturday: Washington state and Pennsylvania. It is not possible to see the increased pollution in Pennsylvania against the white surface from all the snow we had this week. But the... Ray Hoff Two areas of the US had poorish air quality on Saturday: Washington state and Pennsylvania. It is not possible to see the increased pollution in Pennsylvania against the white surface from all the snow we had this week. But the Goddard Space Flight Center MPL lidar showed increased light scattering this afternoon as the temperatures warmed and as the sunlight got stronger. It is likely that nitrate air pollution has added to the mix.

The PM levels in Lancaster PA were unusually high on Saturday and the haze can be seen in webcameras from Frostburg PA to Newark, NJ (below right).

]]> Snow in Northeast; Moderate AQIs in Great Lakes and Northwest tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5399 2015-03-06T21:46:31Z 2015-03-06T21:49:27Z The MODIS Terra image below left shows the new snow in the northeast from the storm over the past few days, as well as the front behind the snow moving offshore. The NWS surface analysis shows the front in more... Daniel Wesloh

The EPA AQI loop below left shows areas of Moderate AQI over the Great Lakes and Pacific Northwest, extending down into the Pacific Southwest starting around noon. The OMI tropospheric NO2 image below right hints that the elevated AQIs around the Great Lakes may be due to nitrate aerosols.


]]> Code Orange in Northern California. Increased Sulfates in Southeast. tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5394 2015-03-03T23:43:32Z 2015-03-04T16:01:08Z The MODIS Aqua AOD image, below left, shows low values of AOD across the country for today. There does appear to be scattered increases in AOD in the western coast of the country and light bands of increased AOD are... John Sullivan The MODIS Aqua AOD image, below left, shows low values of AOD across the country for today. There does appear to be scattered increases in AOD in the western coast of the country and light bands of increased AOD are apparent in Texas and the Gulf of Mexico. The KNMI OMI NRT NO2 product below right, shows increases in NO2 throughout the troposphere. Cloud coverage has made the measurement difficult in the center of the country. There appears to be an increase in the Southeast and Northeast regions. For this reason, there may be some increased nitrate aerosol and particulate formation that will affect air quality at the surface.



Below, left. the GEOS Chem model shows an increase in total AOD for the northeast and New England regions of the U.S. Although this is total species AOD, it is almost entirely sulfate aerosol related. Another AOD increase is centered in the Texas and Southeast region. Below right, courtesy EPA Airnow, shows the animation of the AQI values for the day. The largest values recorded were in Northern California, with a code orange. This enhancement may still be due to residential wood burning in the region.
]]> Dust and Smoke in the South; NO2 and Sulfates over Great Lakes Region tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5393 2015-03-03T04:59:00Z 2015-03-04T06:12:56Z The Mid-Atlantic States, Great Lakes Region, Midwest, and parts of the West Coast in and around Northern California have been experiencing Moderate to Unhealthy AQIs (EPA AirNow Combined Loop, top left). These Unhealthy AQIs peaked near Reno, California a few... Farrah Daham The Mid-Atlantic States, Great Lakes Region, Midwest, and parts of the West Coast in and around Northern California have been experiencing Moderate to Unhealthy AQIs (EPA AirNow Combined Loop, top left). These Unhealthy AQIs peaked near Reno, California a few hours after sunrise, presumably from active fires around the area. Air quality in the Midwest is also being affected by smoke combined with a mixture of dust, sulfates, and NO2. The MODIS AOD image (top right) shows elevated AOD over the Northern Plains States, in agreement with the Moderate AQIs in the area. Light smoke is starting to cross the US border, blowing north from burns in Southern Mexico and Central America. The NAAPS Aerosol Model (bottom left) predicts the smoke surface concentration over the fire sites south of the border to reach 128 µg/m3. The model also predicts dust to reach 10.24 mg/m3 in and around Arizona.

Large concentrations of NO2 can be seen over the Great Lakes Region and the East Coast (OMI NRT Total NO2, bottom right). The model notes sulfates to also be affecting air quality in the East as well as in the Midwest, in agreement with Moderate AQIs in these areas. The sulfate surface concentration is predicted to have reached 8 µg/m3 over Pennsylvania, which could be the reason behind USG AQIs in central Pennsylvania.

]]> Weekend Edition: Moderate AQI east of the Mississippi and clouds everywhere tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5390 2015-03-01T02:32:20Z 2015-03-01T02:44:27Z Pretty simple air quality situation over the US on Saturday. There is moderate AQI for particulates pretty much everywhere east of the Mississippi. However, there are also clouds pretty much everywhere east of the Mississippi. Very little information is added... Ray Hoff Pretty simple air quality situation over the US on Saturday. There is moderate AQI for particulates pretty much everywhere east of the Mississippi. However, there are also clouds pretty much everywhere east of the Mississippi. Very little information is added from spaceborne observations today.

]]> Moderate AQIs in East; Unhealthy in Central California tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5389 2015-02-28T04:59:59Z 2015-02-28T16:04:34Z The EPA AQI loop below left shows Unhealthy AQI in central California, as well as areas of Moderate AQI stretching along the east coast and onto the Gulf coast. The OMI tropospheric NO2 image below right indicates that nitrates may... Daniel Wesloh The EPA AQI loop below left shows Unhealthy AQI in central California,
as well as areas of Moderate AQI stretching along the east coast and
onto the Gulf coast. The OMI tropospheric NO2 image below
right indicates that nitrates may be the cause of the elevated AQIs
in the Mid-Atlantic.

The NPS webcam image below left shows the effect of the elevated AQIs
in central California on visibility at Joshua Tree National Park; at
right are clear and hazy images from the same location for comparison.

The graphic below shows measured PM2.5 concentrations in
southern California and shows several stations approaching the
Unhealthy line.






]]> Snow Covering Much of the United States; alongside elevated AQI tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5387 2015-02-26T04:27:21Z 2015-02-27T00:37:53Z After what's been one of the snowiest and coldest winters in awhile, even parts of the deep-south are feeling the chill. The snowfall footprint stretches from the valleys of California to the nation's Capital, with measured snowfall also across the... Ruben Delgado After what's been one of the snowiest and coldest winters in awhile, even parts of the deep-south are feeling the chill. The snowfall footprint stretches from the valleys of California to the nation's Capital, with measured snowfall also across the southern contiguous U.S. (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia) (top left, courtesy WSI). In terms of air quality, elevated, Code Yellow, Moderate AQIs, were scattered throughout the Pacific North and Southwest, Mid-West, Plains, Great Lakes, Mississippi Valley, Mid-Atlantic and Northeast states (top right). Satellite retrieval of aerosol optical depth (AOD) within these regions was obstructed today, due to immense cloud cover (bottom left); however if you look closely, you can see the spines of the Appalachians peeking through the image as the result of clear skies and a swath of snow cover. Finally, a Code Red, Very Unhealthy AQI, was reported in northeast California. After investigating further, it is unclear if this is an actual measurement of elevated PM2.5 or an artifact from instrument error (bottom right).

]]> Code Red in California. Increased AOD in Southeast. tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5388 2015-02-25T01:26:35Z 2015-02-27T01:41:45Z The VIIRS AOD image, below left, shows low values of AOD across the country for today. There does appear to be scattered increases in AOD near the Pacific coast of southern California. There is also an increase in AOD near... John Sullivan The VIIRS AOD image, below left, shows low values of AOD across the country for today. There does appear to be scattered increases in AOD near the Pacific coast of southern California. There is also an increase in AOD near the northwest corner of Oregon. The KNMI OMI NRT NO2 product below right, shows increases in NO2 throughout the troposphere. There appears to be an increase in the Pacific Northwest and southern California regions. For this reason, there may be some increased nitrate aerosol and particulate formation that will affect air quality at the surface.



Below, left. the GEOS Chem model shows an increase in total AOD for the southeast and Gulf regions of the U.S. The heaviest concentrations appear to be north eastward of the concentrated fire region in the southeast region. Below right, courtesy EPA AIRNOW, shows the code red for eastern southern California. This was most likely due to residential wood burning in the region due to very cold temperatures.
]]> Sulfates and NO2 in East, Dust and Smoke in West tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5391 2015-02-24T04:59:00Z 2015-03-01T16:33:08Z Air quality is pretty clear today except for some areas of Moderate to USG, growing and dispersing in the course of hours with most of the Moderate AQI's residing on the East coast (EPA AirNow, top left). Large concentrations of... Farrah Daham Air quality is pretty clear today except for some areas of Moderate to USG, growing and dispersing in the course of hours with most of the Moderate AQI's residing on the East coast (EPA AirNow, top left). Large concentrations of NO2 through the total column can be seen off the coast of the Mid-Atlantic States (OMI, top right), resulting in elevated AOD's specifically offshore from Maryland (MODIS, bottom left). Sulfates are also predicted to have an effect on air quality off the coast, especially Maryland, predicted to reach 8 μg/m3 (NAAPS, bottom right). The model also predicts dust to reach 5.12 mg/m3 over the border of Arizona and New Mexico. HMS has noted dust/sand kicked up in the Pacific Southwest, carried Southwest by winds from Nevada into California. The AirNow loop shows Unhealthy AQI's growing during the day in Southern California, presumably the noted dust/sand from Nevada. Small plumes of smoke from burns in the Pacific Northwest also seem to be affecting air quality on the West Coast, where spots of USG can be seen popping up throughout the course of the day.

]]> Fires in Southeast; Air Action Day in Southern California tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5386 2015-02-21T04:59:59Z 2015-02-21T13:50:13Z A few fires in the southeast continue, as seen on the MODIS Aqua image and the HMS fire and smoke product shown below (top left and top right, respectively). Fortunately, they seem to be having a limited effect on air... Daniel Wesloh A few fires in the southeast continue, as seen on the MODIS Aqua image
and the HMS fire and smoke product shown below (top left and top
right, respectively). Fortunately, they seem to be having a limited
effect on air quality, as shown in the EPA AQI loop at the bottom right.
The NWS issued a red flag warnings in this area due to low humidity.





The San Joaquin Valley and Los Angeles have declared air action days
due to Unhealthy levels of fine particulate matter, seen in the image
of the EPA air monitoring network above at the bottom left. The NPS
webcam image from Joshua tree National Park, shown below left, seems
to show the effects of this; at the right are clear and hazy images
for comparison.
]]> Special Feature: Carbon Emissions Could Dramatically Increase Risk of U.S. Megadroughts tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5385 2015-02-20T04:38:21Z 2015-02-20T17:18:01Z Droughts in the U.S. Southwest and Central Plains during the second half of the 21st century could be drier and longer than any droughts seen in those regions over the past 1,000 years. In a new study published in... Daniel Orozco

Droughts in the U.S. Southwest and Central Plains during the second half of the 21st century could be drier and longer than any droughts seen in those regions over the past 1,000 years. In a new study published in the journal Science Advances on February 12, 2015, scientists found that continued increases in manmade greenhouse gas emissions will drive up the risk of severe droughts. The study is based on projections from several climate models, including one sponsored by NASA.
"Natural droughts like the 1930s Dust Bowl and the current drought in the Southwest have historically lasted maybe a decade or a little less," said Ben Cook, climate scientist at NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies and at Columbia University. "What these results are saying is we're going to get a drought similar to those events, but it is probably going to last at least 30 to 35 years."
According to Cook and colleagues, the current likelihood of a megadrought--one lasting more than three decades--is 12 percent. If greenhouse gas emissions level off by the middle of the 21st century, the likelihood of megadrought will be more than 60 percent. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to increase along current trajectories throughout the 21st century, there is an 80 percent likelihood of a decades-long megadrought in the Southwest and Central Plains between the years 2050 and 2099.
The scientists ran 17 climate models using both emissions scenarios and then analyzed a drought severity index and two soil moisture data sets. The high-emissions scenario projects an atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration of 1,370 parts per million (ppm) by 2100, while the moderate emissions scenario projects the equivalent of 650 ppm by 2100. Currently, the atmosphere contains 400 ppm of CO2. (Full article: Earh Observatory)

]]> Another Blast of Arctic Cold in the East Coast; Moderate PM2.5 in the East and West Coast tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5384 2015-02-19T04:03:19Z 2015-02-19T16:18:13Z Yesterday's winter storm that brought heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain to much of the south-central U.S. has moved off the east coast. Another surge of even colder arctic air arrived tonight at the east coast and will persist into... Ruben Delgado Yesterday's winter storm that brought heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain to much of the south-central U.S. has moved off the east coast. Another surge of even colder arctic air arrived tonight at the east coast and will persist into the weekend. Location in the Mid-Atlantic and near the Carolinas may experience some of the coldest temperatures since the mid-1990s. The top left image was taken by the Suomi NPP satellite's VIIRS instrument showing clouds associated with the storm off the east coast along with snow in the northeast. Moderate PM2.5 was recorded along the east and west coast. MODIS Aqua AOD over California ranged between 0.1-0.3. Tropospheric NO2 concentrations were high in both coasts indicating that ammonium nitrate production might be dominating particulate matter production over these regions.

]]> Good to Moderate AQIs over US, New Prescribed Fires in Midwest tag:alg.umbc.edu,2015:/usaq//1.5383 2015-02-17T04:59:00Z 2015-02-17T22:22:54Z Snow and rain storms in the Northeast and Southeast respectively brought in a couple inches of precipitation, controlling agricultural fires prescribed last week in the Southeast and helping air quality remain Good to Moderate for most of the day (EPA... Farrah Daham Snow and rain storms in the Northeast and Southeast respectively brought in a couple inches of precipitation, controlling agricultural fires prescribed last week in the Southeast and helping air quality remain Good to Moderate for most of the day (EPA AirNow, top left). Very light, barely detectable, plumes of residual smoke blowing Southeast from Florida, Georgia, and Alabama are crossing over into the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico. Those fires have already--for the most part--cleared, with more heavily concentrated fires now burning in the central Plains States, Florida, Cuba, and Southern Mexico (HMS, top right). The smoke surface concentrations predicted by the NAAPS Aerosol Model (bottom left) over these areas are estimated to reach 32 ug/m3, possibly the reason behind elevated AQIs in the region. Sulfates and tropospheric NO2 (OMI, bottom right) are also affecting air quality on both the East and West coasts. A small spot of USG AQIs was measured in Southern California after sunrise and another in central Oregon.

]]>
